repnme.cdata!:
Algeria - Urban Natural Hazard
            Vulnerability Reduction Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Urban Natural Hazard Vulnerability
            Reduction Project of Algeria had the following ratings:
            outcomes were moderately satisfactory, risk to development
            outcome was moderate, Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory, and borrower performance was moderately
            satisfactory. The lessons learned included: A) The attention
            of decision makers should be focused on preventive
            activities to reduce the vulnerability of urban areas to
            natural disasters; B) Urban development plans should include
            appropriate measures for preventing severe damages due to
            natural disasters, including earthquakes and floods; C)
            Annual budgets of agencies in charge of risk prevention and
            management should include adequate and well identified
            amounts for natural disaster prevention; D) Using the case
            studies of the Ain Temouchent and the Urban Natural Hazard
            Vulnerability projects, the Government should sensitize
            local authorities and technicians to the need to enforce
            preventive measures; E) Local authorities should be fully
            involved in providing relief after natural disasters, as was
            the case following the November 2001 floods; and F) In view
            of the frequency of natural disasters in Algeria, the CAS
            should have included an operation aimed at reducing the
            vulnerability of the country to such disasters.

repnme.cdata!:
Algeria - Urban Natural Hazard
            Vulnerability Reduction Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Urban Natural Hazard Vulnerability
            Reduction Project supports the efforts of the Algerian
            Government in 1) addressing extensive damage caused by the
            floods of November 10, 2001; 2) reducing urban
            vulnerability; and 3) building national capacity for
            disaster management. The financing includes building and
            rehabilitation of flood-related infrastructure, and housing
            units put at risk in the flood-affected communities of the
            Wilaya of Algiers; and studies, training programs, and
            equipment to improve the country's disaster management
            capacity to respond to similar natural hazards.

repnme.cdata!:
Algeria - Urban Natural Hazard
            Vulnerability Reduction Project : environmental impact assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The Urban Natural Hazard Vulnerability
            Reduction Project will strengthen its national capacity for
            disaster management, and reduce urban vulnerability to
            natural hazards. The project's long term impact is
            considered to be essentially positive and will lead to a
            significantly lower vulnerability in the area. The
            environmental impacts of the works involved by the Project
            will be minimal and will be addressed in detail in the
            integrated vulnerability reduction study. The resettlement
            of 5,000 families currently living in areas vulnerable to
            natural hazards is the most serious issue and was analyzed
            very carefully. The new sites for resettlement of the 5,000
            families will be subjected to environmental screening and
            environmental management plans will be prepared as needed to
            ensure that appropriate mitigation measures will be
            implemented and monitored. The project also aims at
            removing, offsetting, or mitigating all impacts of
            unregulated urban development that magnified the adverse
            consequences of the flash floods of November 10, 2001. This
            will be done through works to be carried out on the
            concerned watersheds and embankments, and will include slope
            stabilization by tree plantations, retention basins, and
            drainage collectors.

display_title.display_title:
Algeria - Urban Natural Hazard
            Vulnerability Reduction Project : environmental impact
            assessment : Environmental management framework : executive summary

repnme.cdata!:
Algeria - Urban Natural Hazard
            Vulnerability Reduction Project : resettlement action plan

abstracts.cdata!:
The Urban Natural Hazard Vulnerability
            Reduction Project will re-house affected people in the
            November 2001 floods and people currently living under
            hazardous buildings, vulnerable to mud-flows, floods and
            earthquakes. The Government has prepared a Resettlement
            Policy Framework (RPF) to define all rules and procedures
            related to the re-housing of affected people. The RPF
            defines relevant policies, Algerian laws in effect and
            implementation arrangements, and presents the outlines of
            Resettlement Action Plan (RAP) that will be needed during
            project implementation. The preparation of the RAP will
            follow these steps defined by the RPF: 1) identification and
            minimization of the impacts; 2) social assessment and public
            consultation; 3) definition of the re-housing sites; and 4)
            preparation and implementation of RAP. Eligibility criteria,
            procedures, and modalities of the allocation of social
            rental housing are defined in the Executive Decree 92-48.
            Local authorities will conduct public consultations to
            enable affected people to communicate their needs and expectations.

Resettlement policy framework for people
            affected by the November 10th, 2001 flloods : executive summary
